dcterms:creator: B. Ottersten
P. Stoica
R. Roy
dcterms:description: Covariance fitting (CF) is a comprehensive approach for direction of arrival (DoA) estimation, consolidating many common solutions. It estimates the DoA by identifying the direction at which the sample covariance matrix of the intercepted signal best matches a direction-dependent model.
dcterms:title: Covariance Fitting (CF)

dcterms:creator: X. Pennec
P. Fillard
N. Ayache
dcterms:description: The Affine-Invariant (AI) metric is a Riemannian metric used for covariance fitting, which exploits the Hermitian positive definite structure of covariance matrices.
dcterms:title: Affine-Invariant (AI) metric

dcterms:creator: V. Arsigny
P. Fillard
X. Pennec
N. Ayache
dcterms:description: The Log-Euclidean (LE) metric is a Riemannian metric that approximates the AI metric and allows for efficient calculations on diffusion tensors.
dcterms:title: Log-Euclidean (LE) metric

dcterms:creator: S. Chevallier
E. K. Kalunga
Q. Barthélémy
E. Monacelli
dcterms:description: The Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence is a measure of how one probability distribution diverges from a second expected probability distribution, used in the context of covariance fitting.
dcterms:title: Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence

dcterms:creator: S. Sra
dcterms:description: The Log-Determinant distance is a metric on the manifold of kernel matrices, which is used in covariance fitting applications.
dcterms:title: Log-Determinant distance

dcterms:creator: M. Coutino
R. Pribic
G. Leus
dcterms:description: This dataset involves direction of arrival estimation based on information geometry, focusing on the application of Riemannian metrics.
dcterms:title: Direction of Arrival (DoA) estimation

dcterms:creator: H. Chahrour
R. Dansereau
S. Rajan
B. Balaji
dcterms:description: This dataset focuses on direction of arrival estimation using Riemannian mean and distance, providing insights into the application of Riemannian metrics in signal processing.
dcterms:title: Direction of Arrival (DoA) estimation using Riemannian mean
